Read the hourly OMNI-2 file with fixed-width columns, assign column names, and keep the data in a pandas DataFrame.
Convert index columns (year, day-of-year, hour) into a timezone-aware UTC datetime, divide Kp by 10, and keep only the AP index; then time-slice the DataFrame to 2024-04-01 through 2024-06-30.
Load the satellite TLE file, read it two lines at a time to obtain individual TLE pairs, and build EarthSatellite objects with Skyfield.

For every TLE, compute the semi-major axis in kilometres using the satellite mean motion and Earth’s gravitational parameter μ = 398 600.4418 km³ s⁻², and store the result together with the TLE epoch.
Assemble the epochs and semi-major axes into a DataFrame, sort by epoch, and keep only TLEs dated 2024-05-01 ≤ epoch < 2024-06-01.
Compute the change in semi-major axis between successive TLEs with .diff(), drop the first NaN created by the difference.
Round every TLE epoch to the nearest hour (>= 30 min up, < 30 min down) so that it aligns with the hourly AP grid; if more than one TLE lands in the same hour, average their semi-major-axis changes.
Create two aligned hourly time-series: (1) the rounded-and-averaged semi-major-axis change and (2) the AP index.

For each candidate lag from 0 to 47 hours, shift the AP series forward by that lag so that an AP value at t is compared to a semi-major-axis change at t + lag, inner-join the two series, and compute their Pearson correlation r; square r to obtain r².
Track the lag that yields the maximum r², skipping any lag where fewer than two overlapping points exist, and finally print the best lag together with its r² value.
